Tuesday, 03. May 2022

Verus

March/April 2022 — Verus Monthly Recap

March/April 2022 — Verus Monthly Recap The latest Verus updates on development, community, ecosystem and more. Subscribe to the newsletter here. Next to the monthly recap on Medium, you can receive the exact same content through a newsletter. Subscribe here. I’ll keep things short and to the point. Verus Wins ‘Inspiration Award’ From Fidelity’s Center for Applied Technology Verus was
March/April 2022 — Verus Monthly Recap The latest Verus updates on development, community, ecosystem and more. Subscribe to the newsletter here.

Next to the monthly recap on Medium, you can receive the exact same content through a newsletter. Subscribe here. I’ll keep things short and to the point.

Verus Wins ‘Inspiration Award’ From Fidelity’s Center for Applied Technology

Verus was selected as 1 of 7 finalists, and chosen from hundreds of tech disruptors across Europe. Mike Toutonghi received the award after presenting Verus at a TED Talk-style event in Dublin. It is exciting to see Fidelity and Dogpatch recognize the innovation that the Verus Protocol delivers to the world.

➡️ Read More On the Exciting Win

The developers are working hard towards mainnet before Consensus 2022. In the meantime, new testnet features are on the horizon that will enable more powerful decentralized usecases.

Simplified and improved ID privacy by adding “source of funds” address to registration, enabling a specific ID or z-address to be used for the funds to prepare and register an identity. Advanced sub-ID registration for decentralized identities with new business models, semi-centralized identities for voting and other purposes, and centralized identities that can be issued and sold via centralized currencies. Decentralized fractional currencies can issue identities, depending on their parameters, and the person getting such an ID pays the blockchain identity import fee in native currency as well as the specified fee in the currency issuing the ID. The issuing currency fee is burned, benefitting all holders of the issuing currency by reducing supply by the fee amount and leaving the same reserves, raising conversion rates. Centralized currencies, whether fractional, token, or even native, issue identities and the fees are paid to the controlling ID of the currency, not burned. New “requires permission” and “referral required” issuance is supported. If this is specified as an option in an ID issuing currency definition, which may still be a decentralized issuer, the identity registration transaction must be counter-signed by either the ID of the issuing currency (“requires permission”) or a valid referrer (“referral required”) which either is the issuing currency ID or an unrevoked ID with the same parent as the new identity. The identity registration command and API will enforce this and create transactions that must be signed in this manner. Separate pricing, referral namespaces, and referral levels for all identity namespaces are supported (ie. only *.fanclub@ can refer for name.fanclub@). Pricing of sub-IDs for a fractional currency can be either in the currency itself or denominated in any of its reserves (eg. USD, VRSC, EUR, etc.) to enable compatibility with ID-based rights licensing or royalty streams priced in any currency. Gateway registration for centralized or decentralized non-name controller gateways (the ETH bridge, for example) that allow issuance of, for example, mike.veth@, priced in USD, and paid in Bridge.VETH. Creation of “mapped currencies” using the gateway registered IDs, such as BAT.vETH mapped to Ethereum BAT, for example. Normal sub-IDs cannot create currencies, but this is enabled for gateways that are not name controllers to provide them with services that would be harder for them to write than use from Verus. New Verus Desktop Features

In the upcoming new Verus Desktop release, the Multiverse-tab has been revamped and you’ll be able to get insights into the blockchain economics and easier ways to search for currencies.

Testnet visualization.

Another added feature is that you can visualize the network to see the connections between all the blockchains, bridges and currencies.

Two Videos Where Mike Toutonghi Talks About Verus Awesome Community Mining Rigs

These are publicly shared mining rigs by community members in the Verus Discord. Use for inspiration when you are thinking of mobile mining Verus!

➡️ Mining Verus is easily done with VerusBox or VerusMiner9000.

From community member ‘R86M’From community member ‘NorbyTheGeek@’From community member ‘MaidoK’From community member ‘PhartBox’ Please subscribe to the monthly recap so you’ll get it each month in your mailbox.

14:02 • 2 months ago

Monday, 02. May 2022

Open Meta DAO

The Emergence Protocol: The Role of Game Engines In The Open Metaverse

Why are game engines so important to the future of the Metaverse? And how does Emergence, a key utility of Open Meta™, allow the Open Metaverse? We have seen unbelievable technological leaps and bounds in just 80 years. Now, as we stand on the cusp of Web 3.0 and the Open Metaverse, there’s no telling what life and technology will look like in a year, let alone another 80. One thing we do kno
Why are game engines so important to the future of the Metaverse? And how does Emergence, a key utility of Open Meta™, allow the Open Metaverse?

We have seen unbelievable technological leaps and bounds in just 80 years. Now, as we stand on the cusp of Web 3.0 and the Open Metaverse, there’s no telling what life and technology will look like in a year, let alone another 80.

One thing we do know? Game engines will play an increasingly important role. As more and more of our experiences are immersive, we’ll need tools to develop them.

It’s not that game engines are new. Video games, computers, and Internet technologies have evolved at a breathtaking pace since the first digital computer was developed in 1942. The game Spacewar! was shared amongst programmer circles in the 1960s, starting a cascade that would lead to console wars, id Software’s DOOM! game engine in 1993, and incredible worldwide gaming phenomena like World of Warcraft and Fortnite. When Tim Berners-Lee unveiled the World Wide Web in 1990, nobody could have envisioned that web-connected smartphones would live in millions of pockets within 30 years.

But game engines aren’t just for games anymore.

The Leap From Web 2.0 to Web 3.0

Creative minds build on the accomplishments of their predecessors — they don’t reinvent the wheel every day. If somebody had had to rediscover metallurgy every time they wanted to make something, we would never have made it out of the Stone Age.

The same goes for technological development, especially video games. Our species has become adept at combining previous advancements with modern findings and forward-thinking to create new products and processes.

Our current version of the Internet, Web 2.0, was initially built by web developers, but then co-opted by corporate interests. It brought a lot of positive change and connected people on a global level, but it also came with a lot of baggage.

Web 3.0 and the Open Metaverse are the next stages of the technological revolution. Instead of being centralized and built by the same corporate gatekeepers that developed Web 2.0, this new paradigm promises an immersive digital experience created by game developers. But this doesn’t mean it’s just another video game to play for fun. It is so much more.

What Exactly Is The Open Metaverse?

It feels like the term “Metaverse” is currently being used by every major corporation and tech person in the world, but this has led to a misunderstanding of what it is — and what it can be. The Open Metaverse is not just an immersive VR video game with blockchain mechanics shoehorned in, neither is it a movement to attach crypto Play-to-Earn ideas to video games you already know and love.

Instead of thinking of the Open Metaverse as a video game, think of it as a digital Gamespace. You’re not just playing; you’re adding a digital layer to your physical existence. The Open Metaverse extends your day-to-day life into a new gamified frontier, where you can chase professional and financial opportunities, experience love and heartbreak, freely express yourself, own your digital life and, ultimately, craft your own story.

Developing the Open Metaverse

The next generation of developers is looking beyond the lines of code, building an Open Metaverse that provides an interoperable, secure, open, and community-driven digital future designed for everyone. They realized that they could drop these new features into toolboxes for use by others, thereby freeing up creative minds for more out-of-the-box thinking. This led to the idea of the game engine: a software framework that contains all the necessary libraries, support programs, and tools that are needed to create digital assets and the physics of their interactions.

But while game engines do provide a way to accelerate the growth of Web 3.0 and the Open Metaverse, the main issue is that they are still rooted within Web 2.0. Most of them are publicly traded companies with proprietary offerings, which means profit is the primary motive. They don’t see an Open Metaverse as something that serves their interests as for-profit companies.

Driving the Future With Unity and Unreal

Game engines have become the prime movers for layering the digital on top of the physical, allowing for the creation of digital twins of physical objects and providing a sandbox for testing and exploration. They started as game development frameworks but have expanded to so much more, in such a short space of time.

The undisputed market leaders for game engines are Unity and Unreal. These two juggernauts came onto the scene in the late 90s and early 2000s, furiously evolving and expanding into uses across multiple industries. Since their debuts, these two game engines have grown to account for over 70% of the top 1000 mobile games, attracting millions of developers and making up over 60% of the game engine market.

Both engines are now being used for digital rendering in industries like film, automotive, architecture, civil engineering, and more. The ability to easily create digital twins of physical items, test scenarios with hyper-realistic physics, and create models of products and ideas for presentations has made these the tools of the future.

But there are problems with interoperability and proprietary uses. Unity is a for-profit company that doesn’t have other sources of revenue to help offset licensing of its engine. Epic, the creator of Unreal, has massive revenue streams coming in from Fortnite, but interoperability is limited and it is prohibitively expensive to port a game from Unreal to another engine.

These game engines have amazing potential, but they are still lacking the ingredients we need to construct an Open Metaverse future.

Bringing Game Engines to Web 3.0 With Emergence SDK

The Emergence Software Development Kit (SDK) is the missing piece of the puzzle that will cut across the different game engines and bring interoperable security and sovereignty to users.

The Emergence Agent Interface offers a game-style user interface that will be available in Unity- and Unreal-based programs. The Agent’s functionality is backed by your Personal Stack — a decentralized service architecture allowing for pluggable services and secure storage, completely under your control. The Personal Stack manages content storage for NFTs, digital assets, Universal Feed posts and products, and hosting for marketplaces or other needs.

Emergence is developed as an open source protocol and offered to the community by the Open Meta DAO: a non-profit, decentralized, and community-driven engine pushing for an Open Metaverse and digital self-sovereignty. The DAO’s framework of community Houses and open governance will ensure the Open Metaverse is constructed by the community, for the community, avoiding the pitfalls of Web 2.0.

Developers will be able to use the plug-and-play tools of Unity and Unreal to build the assets and physics of the new virtual worlds. Meanwhile, Emergence will give developers plug-and-play sovereignty and security tools, as well as ensuring the voices of the Open Metaverse community are heard.

Web 3.0 and the Open Metaverse are the next steps in our digital evolution, but they have to be done right. We can’t afford to over-compromise and make a Web 2.5 that ostracizes future generations by adding more elaborate pay schemes to popular game space experiences.

Emergence and the Open Meta DAO will provide the tools needed to construct a digital Game Space that offers privacy, interoperability, and abundance.

These are the vital components that will allow us to realize the words of Richard Buckminster Fuller and become ‘architects of the future, not its victims.’

Join a community that is passionate about the Open Metaverse. Check out our Discord or follow us on Twitter.

12:56 • 2 months ago

Saturday, 30. April 2022

Polkadot Network

Staking Update: April 2022

By Kian Paimani, Parity Technologies Bags-List: One Step User Friendlier. Something that has happened during the last months and deserves a shoutout is both Polkadot.js apps, and the Polkadot.js plus extension supporting bags-list 🎉! In both interfaces, nominators can ensure that they are: Placed in the best possible

By Kian Paimani, Parity Technologies

Bags-List: One Step User Friendlier.

Something that has happened during the last months and deserves a shoutout is both Polkadot.js apps, and the Polkadot.js plus extension supporting bags-list 🎉!

In both interfaces, nominators can ensure that they are:

Placed in the best possible bag given their staked DOTs. Places in the best place inside the bag to which they belong. This is particularly important for those who are near the minimum active nominator threshold.

See the new wiki page related to bags-list on the Polkadot wiki for more details on this!

Nomination Pools update: Wiki page out, Deployed to Westend.

Nomination pools have been the main topic for the last few months, and are becoming one stop closer to mainnet production! As of this writing, the 9.20 release of Polkadot has been finalized, in which the corresponding Westend runtime contains the new nomination pools pallet. Get some Westies (WND) and start experimenting with nomination pools!

Similarly, Polkadot.js Apps now has support for the pools as a new tab, and a new page about nomination pools has been created in the Polkadot Wiki. For other apps, explorers, builders and UIs who want to support nomination pools, you can join the “Nomination Pools UI Support” matrix chat to connect to other builders and ask your questions form us!

We invite everyone who tries out the pools to report any potential bugs to us either via the parity bug-bounty email, or directly to kian@parity.io.

Nomination Pools: Why Bother?

This is a small note about why nomination pools are important for the Polkadot and Kusama ecosystem.

First, looking from the perspective of an intending-nominator, joining a pool has two main benefits:

The limits to receive rewards in the pools will be significantly lower than the limits to receive rewards as a nominator. For example, to be a nominator in Polkadot now, one needs 10 DOTs to nominate, and around 120 DOTs to actively receive rewards. We suspect pools to be deployed such that anyone with as low as 1 DOT can receive rewards. You will have more control over your staking rewards: This may or may not be relevant, but one fundamental difference between the pool members and nominators is that nominators receive their rewards automatically by validators, whereas pool members decide themselves when to receive their rewards.

Next, looking at the validators, the existence of pools is a great opportunity for validators (or a group of validators) to open pools, and attract more staking input into their validators of choice. In essence, the inflow of DOTs into the staking system will inevitably increase with the deployment of nomination pools, and there is an incentive for validators to make sure this inflow is directed toward their validators. This can be particularly interesting to waiting validators.

Notable Contributions

The main code contribution of this month to the staking world has been the main staking-pools PR, along all of its sub-PRs being merged. The most notable of these is the ability of partial unbonding, which has been added now.

Moreover, some changes were made and merged into the details of the signed submission in the election provider pallet, improving the UX of the staking-miner application. More details and updates in the staking-miner coming in the following months!

Thinking about contributing? Look for issues in the Substrate repo with the mentor tag, or the NPoS and Elections project. All successful contributions will get an on-chain tip initiated by the staking team.

Also, if you are interested in contributing long-term, there’s a “Staking / PoS Engineer” position available at Parity Technologies, targeting exactly those who will contribute to the staking system.

By The Numbers

Confused by the meaning of all these terms? What is “intention”? What is “electing/electable”? Then checkout the February update, in which we explained the new staking terminology.

Thursday, 28. April 2022

Horizen - Blog

Horizen Weekly Insider Recap – Weekly Insider #142 June 27 2022

Each Monday, the Horizen team has a public team call to ensure that our community stays up to date on the latest project insights and updates. June 27 2022 Updates Engineering / Product Updates TokenMint Horizen’s TokenMint platform V1 (MVP) is made up of a  tokenization sidechain, a web wallet-Cobalt, a block explorer, and a […] The post Horizen Weekly Insider Recap – Weekly Insider #14

Each Monday, the Horizen team has a public team call to ensure that our community stays up to date on the latest project insights and updates.

June 27 2022 Updates

Engineering / Product Updates

TokenMint

Horizen’s TokenMint platform V1 (MVP) is made up of a  tokenization sidechain, a web wallet-Cobalt, a block explorer, and a token generator to support the economy of your projects, without the need for setup or coding.

Mainnet release is currently in progress. Final rounds of testing performed, bug fix cycle is in progress. Mainnet activities are ongoing, security improvements introduced and safe storage recovery is in testing. 

V2 of the TokenMint Platform (NFT) adds D-POS and the possibility of minting NFTs. The development of the basic support for NTFs is near completion

The EVM Sidechain (EVM M1), which is The Ethereum Virtual Machine sidechain to bootstrap our DeFi has a target completion date of Q3 and we are currently on track. Currently started integration activities with MetaMask, also developing the methods used by Ethereum compatible wallets. 

The Horizen team is also working on our sidechain monitoring system, which is a simple reference design to check the status of a list of sidechains and nodes. The project is currently being deployed on testnet. The next steps for this project are to deploy and use it to monitor our tokenization platform in testnet. 

Zendoo

Last week we finished reviewing the design document about the management of those sidechains whose use case doesn’t require the seizing functionality. The approach we are going to follow is the one focused on the variable epoch. 

There are some sidechains where the mainchain backward transfer request is not required, where we don’t bind the sidechain to answer the request, so with these sidechains we can relax the concept of seizing. The question is how to implement it in an efficient way. After we perform this analysis, the best approach to proceed with is to make a variable epoch length sidechain.   This will allow for example for a sidechain to submit a certificate with a higher or lower rate based on backward transfer requests happening on the sidechain side. This is possible since we don’t have the requirement of posting the certificate and answering mainchain backward requests. 

Furthermore on Zendoo, while exploring the code for changes related to the non-seizing sidechain, we also found a potential area of improvement that is related to shielded transactions. Additional checks have to be performed, but it seems we may be able to introduce an optimization for the PHGR transactions.

SDK

In regards to Blaze we are bringing on the developments related to the next version of Blaze. As part of this we are working on multiple things – forger transactions filtering strategy which has been changed, sorting by fee rate instead of fee, everything has been completed and merged. Regarding improvements to the mem pool where the maximum size limit was added without automatic cleanup strategy per fee rate, is currently under review. Other improvements related to the login system are also under review. 

EVM sidechain  

Metamask now works with the sidechain EVM RPC server. Stake withdrawal request and EOA message processor are completed, which are pretty important for EVM sidechain implementation. We added the chain ID support for the transaction so you are able to specify the chain identifier in the transaction which is another important feature added. EVM execution processor – the implementation has been completed and is currently under review. This is another core part of the EVM sidechain, because it allows the possibility to execute/invoke the EVM, smart contract, specific implementation for staking or withdrawing. Last point is the RPC server wallet related endpoints implementation is currently in process. 

The Proving System

During the last couple of weeks we went on with analysis on various processes and we are deeply analyzing the VM memory management identities, this is part of the SDK EVM strategy.

BD/Operations Updates

We have very good news for our community today. Wintermute, one of the largest market makers, launched their electronic OTC desk called Node, it supports 250+ assets and ZEN is one of them already, with zero fee execution. Node is accessible by US based customers, including in NY state. Need to be an accredited investor or hold over $250K in assets or earn over 100K British Pounds per year. Wintermute node doesn’t have a minimum order size, we are really happy for this new integration and it lowers the barriers of entry for ZEN, big thanks to our partners at Wintermute for supporting us.

Leadership Updates

ZenCon0 – plans have been finalized. We will be hosting our first Horizen ecosystem summit, which we learnt a lot from Zcash’s first event years ago. The location will be in Milan, Italy, Horizen Labs will be hosting a big event there to meet the team. The dates are September 11-13 for public events. The ZenCon0 website has additional information. We will have a limited number of tickets, so we are going to keep it fairly small for this first iteration. We want you to have an inside peek at the team, how we do business, see some presentations, work with us for a few days, and more information coming!

TokenMint – we are on track for the middle of July release here on mainnet, the delay is due to some security enhancements and other changes. We will also launch with a meme coin, not a utility coin, or official coin launch, but it will be a fun token. NFT functionality will be coming next on TokenMint, we are working on trustless sales and other functions. 

Everyone is welcome to check out Rob’s speech from Consensus – the blockchain trilemma and the unique way that Horizen is solving the process.

Horizen Labs hosted an event at NYC.NFT and Zain was also on a panel at the event.

We are doing a lot simultaneously, but in the meantime we are tracking towards that TokenMint mainchain launch, which we are really excited about.

Q & A Section

Q:  Following the general surprise move DYDX moving to Cosmos. Are you seeing any potential shifts to architecture like Horizen given the similarities with Cosmos?

A: Not yet, we are not seeing that, but we are racing to catch up with other protocols and once we become a more well known sidechain platform, with some interesting tokenomics, it will be expected for Horizen to be a solid destination for people who want to do that, so we think the market is still wide open. When you’re dealing with a down market you have more time to build and push products out there. We’ve been thinking about what we can do with tokenomics, incentives and getting more people to launch their chains with us. 

Q: Does Test Zenny holder have some priority for ZenCon0 tickets?

A: It is an Invitation only summit and festival, it is open to anyone in the community who is interested in taking part in this event. There will be a form for people to submit a request to attend for free. We won’t be charging for the ticket, but there is a review process and you will need to submit a form through the event website. More information to come on this. 

Q: When more info on Zenny token mainnet launch?

A: We are going to be kicking off with the meme token. Rob’s thought for Zenny is that it has deep meaningful utility in our ecosystem. We’ve been putting in more effort on this, the meme token is going to be different, more fun at the launch, additional details to come.

Be sure to join us next week, for additional updates from our team. 

Listen to Weekly Insider #142 now on Youtube, Spotify, or iTunes.

Be sure to join our Discord to hear the latest updates each Monday at 11:30 AM EST/ 3:30 PM UTC!

 

The post Horizen Weekly Insider Recap – Weekly Insider #142 June 27 2022 appeared first on Horizen.

a16z Podcast

Inside Apple Software Design

In this wide-ranging conversation from April 2019, a16z’s Frank Chen sits down with Ken Kocienda, a longtime software engineer and designer at Apple from 2001 to 2017, who wrote a book about his career there, called Creative Selection. They discuss Ken’s unconventional path from freelance photographer to software engineer at Apple, his work on many core products from Safari web browser to iPhone,

In this wide-ranging conversation from April 2019, a16z’s Frank Chen sits down with Ken Kocienda, a longtime software engineer and designer at Apple from 2001 to 2017, who wrote a book about his career there, called Creative Selection.

They discuss Ken’s unconventional path from freelance photographer to software engineer at Apple, his work on many core products from Safari web browser to iPhone, iPad, and Apple Watch and features like Autocorrect, what it was like to demo new products for Steve Jobs, and more.

13:00 • 3 months ago

Monday, 25. April 2022

BlockWallet

BlockWallet Partners With Themis

Our latest partnership with Themis brings another integration for BlockWallet users. Themis is a permissionless protocol that enables liquidity providers to collateralize their LP and borrow stablecoins to hedge, speculate or leverage to earn higher yields. Themis also enables users to create anonymous lending between pools of funds and mortgagers of NFTs. When using lending/borrowing proto
Our latest partnership with Themis brings another integration for BlockWallet users.

Themis is a permissionless protocol that enables liquidity providers to collateralize their LP and borrow stablecoins to hedge, speculate or leverage to earn higher yields. Themis also enables users to create anonymous lending between pools of funds and mortgagers of NFTs.

When using lending/borrowing protocols, you might garner unwanted attention by moving large funds from the protocol to your wallet. To stay protected, you can utilize BlockWallet’s Privacy Pools to deposit and mix funds in a smart contract. This removes the link between the protocol and your wallet, making it near impossible to perform a targeted attack.

Unlocking liquidity for the Metaverse & GameFi

As the Metaverse becomes increasingly prevalent in the crypto universe, Themis is at the center of creating liquidity for booming Metaverse and GameFi economies.

Themis lets you leverage Uniswap v3 LP positions to borrow stablecoins and blue-chip assets so your initial capital remains in the Uniswap pool generating yield while unlocking its liquidity for greater capital efficiency. Since Uniswap v3 positions are NFTs, they’ve built the capacity to sign in to the protocol with NFTs as well.

Themis has also launched a utility-driven NFT campaign that rewards users who lend/borrow with NFTs that come with perks like a higher LTV ratio. And in the future, they’ll support using other NFTs as collateral for loans and truly become The Bank of the Metaverse!

About Themis

With Themis, you’ll be able to receive a loan using your NFTs from Uniswap v3 as collateral — something no other protocol currently offers.

This way your liquidity will remain in the pool generating yield while unlocking additional value to use however you wish — the ultimate money lego!

In addition to collateralizing your NFTs, Themis allows you to lend, farm, and even bid on liquidated positions in a Dutch Auction. Themis’ collateralized NFTs will offer much more utility than simply Uniswap v3 in the near future, but stay tuned as we’ll dig into that soon!

About BlockWallet

BlockWallet is a privacy-first non-custodial browser extension wallet where you can store, send or receive crypto and interact with your favorite blockchain apps privately.

As crypto sees mainstream adoption, blockchain’s lack of privacy poses real security risks. BlockWallet is here to ensure that on-chain privacy does not lag behind. The wallet provides a set of advanced privacy tools wrapped in a familiar and user-friendly wallet experience, eliminating friction and making privacy accessible for everyone.

BlockWallet protects you and ensures privacy by default. When you make transactions or interact with blockchain apps, BlockWallet routes all node requests through Privacy Proxies, which masks the IP address and other metadata, that can be used to identify and track you on a blockchain. You can also use the Privacy Pools feature, powered by zk-SNARKs technology, to deposit and mix funds in a smart contract. This allows transferring funds without links to your history and identity on the blockchain, effectively rendering them untraceable. BlockWallet offers integrated Flash-Bot Protection, shielding you from sandwich attacks when you trade on DEXes. Meanwhile, the Phishing Protection feature combats phishing scams by generating unique artwork on all sensitive pages.

BlockWallet is not a compromise. It’s privacy-first, but it still packs all features you would expect from a wallet. With full Web 3.0 support, the wallet allows you to connect to any dApp.

Become a part of the BlockWallet community today:

Homepage | Medium | Twitter | Telegram | Discord | GitHub | E-mail

BlockWallet Partners With Themis was originally published in BlockWallet on Medium, where people are continuing the conversation by highlighting and responding to this story.

17:45 • 3 months ago

Friday, 22. April 2022

Wasabi Wallet

Risks Associated with Address Reuse

Addresses are designed to receive bitcoin and are supposed to be disposable with every use. Unless your money matters are meant to be public, reusing an address will always make sure your balances are open for everyone to see.


Yes, address reuse is bad for your privacy. It's the easiest way to lose privacy when transacting with Bitcoin. Until a bitcoin user understands this, their privacy remains out of their control while jeopardizing the privacy of others transacting with them.

A bitcoin address can be likened to a digital "invoice" used to accept payment on the blockchain. It acts as an intended destination for payment on the blockchain. An address is generated from a wallet in the form of a string of 26-35 characters and is shared with the party who intends to pay you in bitcoin. Any funds sent to an address are under the control of its originating bitcoin wallet.

Address reuse is when a user uses one address for more than one transaction. But what makes address reuse so bad for privacy? What risks does it extend to other users transacting with you?

To bring the matter to light it's useful to understand what happens under the hood when we reuse an address.

Many users are now getting familiar with the fact that bitcoin transactions are stored on a public ledger which acts like an open receipt book containing all inbound and outbound transactions from all addresses. Anyone can view transactions associated with an address even without sophisticated tools, for example here. However, the only information a viewer can get is the bitcoin transacted into and out of an address.

When you pay or receive bitcoin, the address(es) associated with the transaction can be viewed. However, due to the pseudonymous nature of bitcoin addresses, this is not enough information to reveal the real-world identity of a user.

Despite the anonymity offered, bitcoin addresses only act as an alias involved in a transaction on the blockchain. It takes a single transaction to reveal enough information about the identity of the user and every transaction associated with an address opens a door to traceability. With each transaction, more information about the user is revealed and available for possible real-world identification.

Users transacting with addresses belonging to users whose privacy has been compromised risk losing their privacy through association. One address reuse is enough to give away your privacy even years after it’s long-forgotten because the blockchain is immutable. Once on the blockchain, forever on the blockchain.

Address reuse is intentional when a user only uses one address to receive and store unspent coins. Such cases may be due to habit, the need to maintain trust, or availability. An example of such address reuse happens on exchanges and donation addresses. As bitcoin users, we may also intentionally send bitcoin to the same address to others resulting in address reuse. This type of address reuse is the most rampant affecting half of all bitcoin users.

For some use cases, address reuse may happen when a user owns a single address wallet or paper wallet. Single address wallets are meant to offer convenience and ease to the users by generating a single address that is meant to receive and store their unspent change. In the case where a user prefers privacy, they are better suited to using Deterministic Address Pool Wallets that generate new addresses for new transactions. Paper wallets, on the other hand, may always require the user to be physically present to make a transaction.

Addresses are designed to receive bitcoin and are supposed to be disposable with every use. When the address is reused, the owner's balance user is open on the ledger. As a business or individual using bitcoin to receive payments, the amount of revenue or balance may always be known if it is tied to one address. Unless your money matters are meant to be public, reusing an address will always make sure your balances are open for everyone to see.

With a discovered identity associated with an address, the user faces the risk of censorship. For example, an address observed donating funds to an activist may be blacklisted from exchanges, and addresses sending funds to the activist may risk being targeted as adversaries in dictatorial states.

Address reuse facilitates surveillance. If you transact with one address, it is easy to generate a relationship graph of who you transact with, where your money goes and who you receive it from. Every single piece of your financial information will be ushering you into the arms of many surveilling organizations that are always analyzing and tracking transactions on the public ledger. Despite the distance between conspiracy and fact about the level of surveillance on bitcoin, it’s important to understand that present technology is potent in allowing full deanonymization of bitcoin transactions.  A little more effort is required by a user to be free from such surveillance but changing addresses does enough to keep your transactions hard to trace.

With all the apparent risks that address reuse poses to privacy, transacting with a new address for every transaction is about care, that the amount of privacy you have is transmissible to every user you transact with. It’s not necessary to understand the intricacies of bitcoin to use the technology safely.  Picking a good wallet that allows you to generate fresh addresses for every new transaction is good enough. Bitcoin allows us the generation of new addresses whenever we need them. This feature was meant to preserve anonymity. All coins sent to every address generated are always under our control meaning we can transact with as many addresses as we need. The convenience of reusing addresses has the price of privacy.

Thursday, 21. April 2022

a16z Podcast

Tesla and the Nature of Disruption

In this re-run from September 2018, Benedict Evans and Steven Sinofsky talk all about Tesla — and more broadly, the nature of disruption overall. How disruptive is Tesla really, and what exactly are they disrupting — from the dashboard to car makers to vendors to energy source to autonomy overall? The tech industry is littered with leading innovators... who nonetheless failed to be the domin

In this re-run from September 2018, Benedict Evans and Steven Sinofsky talk all about Tesla — and more broadly, the nature of disruption overall. How disruptive is Tesla really, and what exactly are they disrupting — from the dashboard to car makers to vendors to energy source to autonomy overall?

The tech industry is littered with leading innovators... who nonetheless failed to be the dominant leader in the end. So the question should be, is this new thing fundamentally difficult for the incumbent to do, and how does it relate to market dominance? Which of these things are important in order for Tesla to be the new BMW or the new GM? Looking back at other examples historically (Microsoft, GM's Saturn Brand, and of course the iPhone), what kind of disruption matters most for market dominance? And what is the long view of how software is eating transportation?

Verida

Verida Q1 2022 Review

Verida Q1 Update 2022 has been off to the races. We welcome a global reopening as the world seems ready to go back to normal life after the Omicron variant left the world with no place to hide. Meanwhile, geopolitical tensions continue to rise and also shape the evolution of crypto and Web3 across sovereign nations. Now more than ever, sovereign identity and data are becoming increasingly imp
Verida Q1 Update

2022 has been off to the races. We welcome a global reopening as the world seems ready to go back to normal life after the Omicron variant left the world with no place to hide. Meanwhile, geopolitical tensions continue to rise and also shape the evolution of crypto and Web3 across sovereign nations.

Now more than ever, sovereign identity and data are becoming increasingly important as people around the world seek to maintain a borderless and digital identity across isolating barriers.

Verida continues to build full-speed ahead to deliver on our roadmap in our quest to make self-sovereign identity and private data in Web3 work for an increasingly complex society. Here are the latest developments from our first quarter highlights.

The Verida Whitepaper

We began the year by sharing the blueprint of the Verida vision with our 45-page whitepaper. It brings to focus what we believe Web2 has wrong with identity, and details use cases that demonstrate how we are reimagining industries for the better with our protocol, token, and network.

Check out our Twitter Spaces conversation with Verida founders Chris Were and Ryan Kris for a breakdown of the Whitepaper and Verida’s vision.

Partnership Expansion

In January we launched the Verida Early Adopter Program for projects building innovative Web3 applications leveraging the Verida Network.

Four new partners have been signed on since then, providing decentralized solutions in areas such as community DAOs, data marketplaces, insurance, and financial compliance. We welcome to the Verida ecosystem:

Nimble — a decentralized insurance protocol, building on Algorand Webblen — a decentralized social platform and data marketplace, building on Algorand QSTN — a decentralized community engagement rewards platform, building on NEAR FinClusive — a hybrid RegTech/FinTech company providing solutions for regulatory compliance in banking and finance, supporting multiple blockchains

You can keep track of the latest partners utilizing the Verida network on our new ecosystem page.

If you are interested in joining our Early Adopter Program, check out our announcement and reach out to us on Discord to learn more about how you can get on board!

In March we announced the expansion of our relationship with NEAR, after securing a grant from the NEAR Foundation to enhance the Verida Vault with specific capabilities to support their protocol.

These new features specific to NEAR will include single sign-on support returning a key pair, the creation of implicit accounts, identification of named accounts, support for viewing, sending, and receiving NEP-141 tokens, and support signing of transactions via WalletConnect.

We’ll continue to provide updates as these features become available on NEAR, keep up to date by joining our Discord server for the latest.

Product & Engineering Updates

We had quite a bit of progress in our engineering development, getting us ever closer to the much-anticipated Mainnet and Verida token launch, as well as the Verida Vault MVP launch on Testnet.

We also laid out how the Verida Network serves our mission for achieving self-sovereignty of personal data, and outlined how our infrastructure works in our Whitepaper in greater detail. Here is a recap of the important highlights in case you missed it:

Verida Protocol

The first phase of region-aware public Testnet infrastructure is currently undergoing QA. An upgrade of the protocol signature scheme that supports signing data with schema information, but without schema version. This provides increased interoperability in the future when dealing with data migrations. The SSO developer SDK has been updated to support a much simpler authentication configuration. Significant progress has been made on the core Verida smart contracts that will be integrated into the protocol libraries during Q2 The Verida Account Explorer has been developed and is currently live on the Testnet.

Verida Vault MVP

Verida Vault MVP on Testnet to be released in the App Store in Q2, with Android to follow. Join our #developer-preview Discord channel to get early access to our soft release. You can reference how to get started here on how to gain the most benefits from using Verida Vault Web3 #BUIDLers can learn more about how to take advantage of our suite of product integrations to connect to the Verida Network here. Our Verida Vault continues to evolve as well as we continue to increase the multi-chain support capabilities available to users.

The Verida Whitepaper: Our Vision, Our Technology, explained

We made a big announcement in February to explain why Verida exists, why we’re building what we’re building, and how it all works. If you still haven’t read it yet, you really should. If you’re a true #Veridian and already live and breathe our mission, you can head straight to the meat and potatoes (the whitepaper) here.

Developers Docs Refresh

We’ve refreshed our Developer Documentation which includes new features such as interactive tutorials with live editors to get developers started on Verida quickly and easily. As a reminder, we also provide a number of reference implementations to showcase what you can do with the Vault:

Vault Showcase — This demo showcases how you can send or request data and messages on the network using Verida Vault. Watch our 45-second video on how to connect your Vault wallet using Single-Sign-On here. Account Explorer — This is a new application designed to show the public profile of any user on the Verida network Markdown Editor — a Decentralized Note App that integrates with the Verida Datastore library and Verida Vault allowing users to save encrypted notes to their database. Credentials Management Platform — Our demo application demonstrates the creation of Verifiable Credentials using your Verida DIDs. Watch our 60-second tutorial on how to send and receive Verifiable Credentials here. Community & Marketing

Verida continues to accelerate awareness of our blockchain and development, by bringing on full-time staff for marketing and business development, getting back to the roadshows, and opening up our products for partnership and development by attending notable events across the globe, like ETHDenver and Blockchain Week Australia.

Our US-based Marketing Manager, Adam Boujida, represented Verida at ETHDenver resulting in lots of exciting connections and opportunities in the pipeline The rest of the Australia-based Verida Core team, Chris Were, Ryan Kris, Nick Lothian, and Yolanda Sam were everywhere to be found at Blockchain Week Australia. Check out the Verida Twitter Spaces recording for the recap. We held a series of ​​fortnightly live streams called #FiresideFridays to provide our community with an opportunity to tune in, hear from the founders discussing data ownership, interesting web3 projects, and the latest product and community updates from Verida (check out one of our conversations with Blockchain Pro here)

Our community continues to grow around the world as we rolled out our Early Adopter Program, and increased engineering and grant support for partners developing innovative and cutting-edge use cases using the Verida network.

Lastly, we were excited to hold our first Verida Ambassadors call earlier in February, and a second in March, where we welcomed our most active community supporters from around the world, with representation from countries like Ukraine and Turkey.

Verida IRL

We continue to hit roadshows and conferences around the world. In the last few weeks, we’ve made several connections at Bitcoin Miami, and Paris Blockchain Week. Come meet the team IRL at the following upcoming events in Q2:

ETHAmsterdam (Netherlands) Graph Day (San Francisco, CA) Permissionless (West Palm Beach, FL) Consensus by Coindesk (Austin, TX) ETHCC Conference (Paris, France)

To find us, just reach out to us Discord and let us know you’re around!

Stay connected with Verida Follow us on Twitter: https://twitter.com/verida_io Join the conversation on Discord: https://discord.com/invite/qb6vS43 View our code on GitHub: https://github.com/verida/ View our Developer Documentation: https://developers.verida.io/ Reach out to us on Telegram: https://t.me/verida_community Subscribe on YouTube: https://www.youtube.com/channel/UC4FkEDSI7Kart2wNjj9Iozw Check out our Community Site: https://community.verida.io/ Discuss on our Reddit: https://www.reddit.com/r/Verida/

Wednesday, 20. April 2022

Home

xx messenger update — Account Backup

A big new feature is coming to the xx messenger [...] Read More... from xx messenger update — Account Backup The post xx messenger update — Account Backup appeared first on xx network.

Today, we are excited to announce that we are launching the first big feature update for the xx messenger — Account Backup.

Upon updating your messenger, within settings you will now be able to select your own cloud service provider to backup your account. This will allow you to set a recovery password and store an encrypted backup of your account on that provider.  

This backup contains your username and your contacts. It currently does not backup chats, group chats, or requests. Once a backup is restored, your contacts will be prompted to reopen the app in order to restore connections.

This backup system is unique in that it allows you to select your own cloud service provider in order to execute the backup.  We currently support Google Drive, Apple iCloud, and DropBox. We plan to add more providers in future updates, including allowing you to select your own personal SFTP server.

As you have probably seen from the teasers we have been releasing, the next step for the xx messenger is an upgrade of the UX and how the app flows in general. 

If you haven’t had a chance to check out these recent teaser videos you can find them all on our YouTube channel here. Just click on the “Videos” tab to see videos in order of most recent release. 

As always, we love to hear community feedback so if you have any questions, comments, or just plain old encouragement for the hard working developers, I know they would like to hear from you. 

Feel free to drop comments in our Discord #xx-messenger channel, or our friendly neighborhood Telegram channel. 

Thanks everyone. Onwards and Upwards! 

The xx messenger is a quantum secure, untraceable messaging platform that enables people around the world to communicate privately and securely.  

You can learn more about the xx messenger here and find the app and updates on  Google Play and the Apple App Store now. Or get the source code yourself from the xx network website. 

The post xx messenger update — Account Backup appeared first on xx network.

17:47 • 3 months ago

BlueYard Capital

Privy

Owning and managing user data has turned from an asset to a liability for most applications and services. This is especially true for web3 projects where, even if encrypted, sensitive user data should never be stored on-chain, as this makes the assumption that the chain’s contents will never be decrypted at any time in the future. As a general rule, blockchains excel at transparency, enforci

Owning and managing user data has turned from an asset to a liability for most applications and services. This is especially true for web3 projects where, even if encrypted, sensitive user data should never be stored on-chain, as this makes the assumption that the chain’s contents will never be decrypted at any time in the future.

As a general rule, blockchains excel at transparency, enforcing provable claims, partially due to the architectural decision that they store all of their state as publicly accessible, immutable data. Also, most chains are not suited for direct data storage (and frequent retrieval) and accommodating large user data volumes would lead to chain bloat with consequences on speed and cost. Hence the following conundrum.

As many web3 developers have chosen to simply not store contextual user data in reaction to these constraints, the user experience of web3 applications suffers. Without user data, developers are flying blind, forced to build for wallets rather than people, with no real insight into the users behind the usage that can be seen on-chain. Also, for many reasons (governance, community, access, compliance, etc.) many web3 projects are increasingly requesting and storing sensitive user data off-chain — using legacy web2 services and home-grown databases, creating unnecessary vulnerabilities for web3 projects and their users.

Enter Privy, which provides powerful APIs and encrypted storage that close the gap between users’ on-chain activity and their off-chain data, empowering developers to build delightful user experiences without putting users’ data at risk. Privy is the web3 connected sensitive data vault for projects / applications, and the data is encrypted so neither the developers nor Privy ever see it. .

With a few extremely simple API calls, such as `privy.put()` and `privy.get()`, developers can encrypt user data directly from the front-end, and privately associate data to on-chain addresses. This enables developers to, e.g.:

Text or email users without handling their personal information directly, Take on financial and compliance data without storing it on their stack, Surface a unified UI across a user’s various wallets across chains without doxxing them.

Our Thesis

Whereas “user data as a liability” is increasingly an established problem in web2 / SaaS, web3’s data infrastructure and ethos around privacy created a much more urgent need to find a robust solution that integrates natively into web3 where required. This should also unlock new user experiences, making web3 more accessible and competitive.

However, this is just the beginning. As web3 matures, there will be an opportunity to reinvent the data paradigms that have failed the internet over the last 30 years and give users back control over their data online. The next generation of data tooling should keep users in the loop and in control of their data across the web. That is why we are excited to back Henri and Asta given their unique and rare capabilities straddling very hard web3 and computer science & software engineering challenges. Read more here.

16:40 • 3 months ago

Privy

We’ve raised an $8M Seed round, led by Sequoia and BlueYard Capital, to help you protect user data…

We’ve raised an $8M Seed round, led by Sequoia and BlueYard Capital, to help you protect user data in web3 Today, we’re excited to announce the latest milestone for Privy: we’ve raised $8.3M in seed funding led by Sequoia Capital and BlueYard Capital. This funding will help us grow our team, scale our APIs and build partnerships to help developers in the space build better, more private prod
We’ve raised an $8M Seed round, led by Sequoia and BlueYard Capital, to help you protect user data in web3

Today, we’re excited to announce the latest milestone for Privy: we’ve raised $8.3M in seed funding led by Sequoia Capital and BlueYard Capital. This funding will help us grow our team, scale our APIs and build partnerships to help developers in the space build better, more private products for their users.

The Round.

We’re so thankful to our backers including Electric Capital, Archetype, BoxGroup, Protocol Labs, as well as amazing builders responsible for some of the best products in web2 and web3 like Aaron Henshaw and Joe Lallouz (Bison Trails), Juan Benet, Molly Mackinlay, Jesse Clayburgh (Protocol Labs), Brad Burnham (USV, Placeholder), Jutta Steiner (Parity, Ethereum), Diogo Monica (Anchorage), Sina Habibian (Ethereum Foundation), Ben Fisch (Espresso Systems), Colfax Selby (GitPoap), John Zannos and Alex Lange (Inflection Capital), Pamir Gelenbe, Eli Turlington and Barron Jeter (Libertus Capital), Sabrina Hahn, Aaron Harris, Ali Rowghani (YC), Nicolas Chinot, Romain Huet, Keith Adams, Ela Madej and Chris Waclawek (50Y), Garry Tan (Initialized), Chad Byers (Susa), Kevin Zhang (Bain Crypto), Nicholas Chirls (Notation), Charlie Songhurst, Kent Beck, Thomas Bailey, anons, and many others!

Why Privy?

Over 300 million people own crypto today, DeFi has $100Bn TVL, Bored Apes have gone viral. Whether you like it or not, you can’t miss crypto (we like it :D).

However, even as the space stands to reshape much of the Internet, finance and our culture, this broader adoption of crypto puts developers building in web3 in a challenging position. More users means more data. More data, more problems.

Personal data today comes with regulatory overhead, breaches and deep misalignment with users — and most developers don’t want to get near it. Yet, without user data, we are flying blind, forced to build for wallets rather than people, with no real insight into our users behind the usage we see on-chain.

And the seams show. The lack of user data in web3 has resulted in terrible user experiences for those accustomed to the modern web. Things like the inability to get an email when you’re about to get liquidated, or the need to keep signing in and out of dapps to see activity across wallets. You shouldn’t have to mine your users’ data or put your users at risk to ship great products.

Developers are busy enough trying to ship brilliant products without having to think through reinventing the data stack. We need better tooling to manage user data privately in web3.

Enter Privy.

Privy builds simple, powerful APIs to manage user data so you can integrate user data into your product easily. Privy helps you bridge the gap between users’ on-chain activity and their off-chain data so you can build delightful experiences without putting your users or product at risk. With privy.put() and privy.get(), encrypt user data directly from your front-end, and privately associate data to on-chain addresses. This enables you to:

Text or email users without handling their personal information directly Take on financial and compliance data without storing it on your stack Surface a unified UI across wallets and across chains without doxxing your users

This is just the beginning. The next generation of data tooling should keep users in the loop and in control of their data across the web. As web3 matures, we see an opportunity to reinvent the data paradigms that have failed us over the last 30 years and give users back control over their data online. We’re so excited to be building with you all!

In case you were wondering, we are hiring ;).

If the opportunity to help reinvent the data stack online is as exciting to you as it is to us, we’d love to speak with you. To get started using our APIs or learn more about Privy, request an API key here or follow us on Twitter. We can’t wait to share more with you soon.

The next generation of data tooling should keep users in the loop and in control of their data across the web. With that, back to work!

The Privy founders

Asta and Henri

We’ve raised an $8M Seed round, led by Sequoia and BlueYard Capital, to help you protect user data… was originally published in Privy Blog on Medium, where people are continuing the conversation by highlighting and responding to this story.
